message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and synovial fluid analysis suggest a possible septic arthritis. The presence of gram-negative rods also suggests an infectious origin. Cefepime is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers gram-negative rods and is often used for septic arthritis treatment. The other options do not cover gram-negative rods or are not appropriate for this particular case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, synovial fluid aspiration, and gram stain suggest the presence of a joint infection caused by gram-negative rods, most likely an Enterobacteriaceae. Among the options, IV cefepime should cover most Enterobacteriaceae. IV vancomycin is not appropriate as it does not cover gram-negative pathogens. IV nafcillin is not appropriate as it does not cover gram-negative pathogens and is not effective in treating joint infections. IV ceftazidime and gentamicin may be effective, but cefepime provides broader coverage and is a better choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest septic arthritis, and the synovial fluid aspirate shows gram-negative rods. Cefepime is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that can cover gram-negative bacteria and is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy in this scenario. Vancomycin is not necessary as gram-negative rods are less likely to cause infections in prosthetic joints.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest septic arthritis, which can be caused by gram-negative rods such as Escherichia coli. IV cefepime is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against gram-negative bacteria and is a preferred treatment for septic arthritis. IV vancomycin is not effective against gram-negative bacteria and the other two options do not cover gram-negative rods.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a joint infection with gram-negative bacteria, which requires a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Cefepime is a cephalosporin antibiotic with good coverage against gram-negative organisms and is a common choice for treating joint infections. Vancomycin is not effective against gram-negative organisms, and nafcillin is not a good choice for gram-negative infections. Ceftazidime and gentamicin is another suitable option, but it carries a higher risk of nephrotoxicity compared to cefepime.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest septic arthritis, which is commonly caused by gram-negative bacteria. Cefepime is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers gram-negative bacteria and is considered the most appropriate pharmacotherapy in this case. Vancomycin would not be effective against gram-negative bacteria, and nafcillin and ceftazidime do not have broad enough coverage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and synovial fluid aspiration findings suggest that the most likely cause of the knee pain is a bacterial joint infection. Among the options, cefepime has broad-spectrum coverage and is commonly used for the treatment of bacterial joint infections. The gram-negative rods suggest that cefepime would be more effective than nafcillin or vancomycin, which are mostly effective against gram-positive bacteria. Ceftazidime and gentamicin would also be effective against gram-negative bacteria, but gentamicin carries a higher risk of nephrotoxicity in the elderly, and cefepime is a reasonable first-line choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of a joint infection, also known as septic arthritis. The gram-negative rods seen on the synovial fluid aspiration suggest the most likely causative agent is gram-negative bacteria. Among the options, IV cefepime is the best choice for gram-negative coverage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of gram-negative rods in the synovial aspirate suggests an infection with a gram-negative organism. Nitrofurantoin may have contributed to this infection. Among the options, cefepime is the most appropriate choice as it covers gram-negative organisms and has good penetration of joint fluid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with septic arthritis, including severe pain, joint stiffness, and warm, erythematous swelling in the affected joint. The presence of gram-negative rods in the synovial fluid indicates a bacterial infection, and cefepime is a commonly used antibiotic for gram-negative infections. Nafcillin is used for gram-positive infections, while ceftazidime and gentamicin are used for more severe infections. Vancomycin would only be used if the patient has a known or suspected allergy to cephalosporins.
